likes: Developers seek automation of development workflows that speed up time to delivery without hassle.
Developers tend toward scientific and engineering pursuits with a structured problem-solving mindset.
Developers vary in choice of operating system but more likely to be on macOS or linux.
Developers seek to build new skills with technology trends and approaches to increase future job prospects or for use on future projects.
Developers prefer clear and helpful documentation is key to success, though would prefer to not have to read it when technology is intuitive to use.
Developers will trust peer recommendations over vendor claims.
Developers seek the existence of a vibrant community is an indicator of technology that will remain longer term.
Developers in technology industries tend to be playful and participate in internet pop culture with a sci-fi or fantasy influences (stereotype).
Developers want control over their destiny, so transparency is preferred over black-box solutions that do not provide an escape hatch should a new requirement emerge.
dislikes: Developers distrust sensational claims using language that is perceived as empty or markety making sensational hyperbolic statements using business jargon.
Developers skip White papers or other gated content that requires signing up for spam email when motivated to learn something new.
Developers avoid repetitive tasks that lack mental stimulation.
Developers will identify errors in documentation or code samples and is a common pet peeve that leads to a lack of trust of the product overall.
Developers dislike adding complexity (that they don't build themselves), slowing performance, introducing risk of on-time delivery, or other unreliable behavior
Developers are wary of a lack of community activity, unresolved/unresponded tickets, etc. will discourage from use of tools from that community.
Developers despise wasting time on frivilous or tasks that are deemed not worth mental energy. Would rather solve interesting problems than file paperwork.

product: Troubleshooting guides for any difficult to understand or new features earn trust that team knows and is working on it.
education: The learning modality influences the types of educational content in tutorials, reference, etc.
Share technical details to prove a claim is valid. Focus is on the how for learning and will often match that tool to various whys themselves.
An onboarding checklist that can be given to developers can go a long way to showing them a path.
communications: Direct and concise is a better communication style.
sales: An inherent laziness is a common virtue of developers, will appreciate logic on how a problem is less busy work for them
Will rigorously evaluate and likely kick the tires trying to make the product fail before considering for adoption.
May want to self-service initially before engaging with meetings because of the immediate gratification that comes from learning right away.
If only option is to speak to a salesperson, will likely evaluate other solutions or open-source alternatives first and may pick those before giving an alternative a chance.
Proof of value explorations may often compare three similar products in order to select the best fit among the options.
Partner with a technical resource like a solutions engineer or developer advocate to be able to address any questions or objections when engaging
Generally devs will not want to negotiate and just want to be able to use the product for a transparent price
marketing: Skeptical of any claims and language that sound sensational hyperbole.
Role often has chaning requirements so emphasis on flexibility, speed and performance, and customization are often good points
Avoid buzzwords and try to use appropriate terminology that removes ambiguity
How something is made, behind the scenes, earns respect for the value of a solution. That helps convince a developer to use rather than build it themselves.
